title: Walkabout
brief_description: Two school children are stranded in the Outback by their father. With no way to fend for themselves, they’re saved by a chance encounter with a First Nations teenager in Nicholas Roeg’s classic film.

constellations_other.name: Landscape as Character
constellations_other.description: The landscape is often a character in Australian films. Usually, it's a villain that represents our problematic national character and is increasingly used to challenge our troubled history and explore our evolving identities.

description: Under the pretense of having a picnic, a geologist takes his teenage daughter and 6-year-old son into the Australian outback and attempts to shoot them. When he fails, he turns the gun on himself, and the two city-bred children must contend with harsh wilderness alone. They are saved by a chance encounter with an Indigenous boy who shows them how to survive, and in the process underscores the disharmony between nature and modern life.
